subject: statistics
title: P-Values: Definition and Interpretation
contentHtml: P-values are a fundamental concept in hypothesis testing. They provide a measure of the probability of observing the data (or more extreme data) under the null hypothesis.

problem.statementHtml: Suppose we want to test whether the average height of students in a class is different from 170 cm. We collect a random sample of 30 students and find that the mean height is 172 cm with a standard deviation of 5 cm.

workedExample.problemHtml: We want to test whether the average score on a math test is different from 80. We collect a random sample of 50 students and find that the mean score is 82 with a standard deviation of 10.

steps.explanation: We're using a two-sample t-test to compare our sample mean to the hypothesized value.
The p-value represents the probability of observing a test statistic at least as extreme as ours, assuming the null hypothesis is true.
If our p-value is below a certain significance level (e.g., 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the average score is different from 80.
If our p-value is below the significance level, we can conclude that our result is statistically significant.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The average score on a math test is different from 80.

intuition: P-values help us determine whether our results are due to chance or if there's a real effect.

subject: statistics
title: P-Values: Definition and Interpretation
contentHtml: P-values are a fundamental concept in statistical hypothesis testing. They represent the probability of observing the test statistic (or more extreme) under the null hypothesis.

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we want to test whether the average height of students in a class is different from 170 cm, with a sample mean of 172 cm and standard deviation of 5 cm. We have n = 30 observations.

steps.explanation: We're using a one-sample t-test to compare our sample mean to the known population mean.
The p-value represents the probability of observing a test statistic at least as extreme as our observed value, assuming the null hypothesis is true.

steps.description: Compare the p-value to the significance level
steps.explanation: If the p-value is less than alpha, we reject the null hypothesis; otherwise, we fail to reject.
Since our p-value (0.02) is less than alpha (0.05), we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the average height of students in the class is likely different from 170 cm.

intuition: P-values provide a way to quantify the evidence against the null hypothesis. A low p-value indicates strong evidence against the null, while a high p-value suggests that the data is consistent with the null.

subject: statistics
title: P-Values: Definition and Interpretation
contentHtml:
P-values are a fundamental concept in statistical hypothesis testing.

  • We'll explore their definition, interpretation, and common misconceptions.
statementHtml: Given a test statistic with a p-value of 0.03, what can we conclude?
problemHtml: A study claims that a new treatment increases patient satisfaction by 10%. The p-value is 0.02. What do we conclude?
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Understand the null hypothesis", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "The null hypothesis states that there's no significant difference in patient satisfaction."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Interpret the p-value", "mathHtml": "\(p = 0.02\)", "explanation": "A small p-value indicates strong evidence against the null hypothesis."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Draw conclusions", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "Since the p-value is below a typical significance level (e.g., 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the treatment has a significant effect on patient satisfaction."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Consider the alternative hypothesis", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "The alternative hypothesis states that the treatment increases patient satisfaction by 10%, which is supported by the data."} ],
finalAnswer: Reject the null hypothesis and conclude the treatment has a significant effect." },
intuition: P-values represent the probability of observing the test statistic (or more extreme values) under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true.

subject: statistics
title: P-Values: Definition and Interpretation

problem.statementHtml: A study claims that a new medication reduces blood pressure by an average of 5 mmHg with a standard deviation of 2 mmHg. We want to test the null hypothesis that the true mean reduction is zero against a two-sided alternative.

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we observe a sample mean reduction of 4 mmHg with a standard error of 1.5 mmHg. What is the p-value for this test?

steps.explanation: This step standardizes the observed effect size.

steps.description: Look up the z-score in a standard normal distribution table or use a calculator
steps.explanation: We're finding the probability of observing this extreme result (or more extreme) assuming the null hypothesis is true.

steps.description: Find the p-value by integrating the standard normal distribution up to our z-score
steps.explanation: The p-value represents the probability of observing this extreme result (or more extreme) assuming the null hypothesis is true.

steps.description: Compare the p-value to a significance level
steps.explanation: If the p-value is below our chosen significance level (e.g., \alpha = 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis.
Since the p-value is very small, we conclude that there is strong evidence to support the alternative hypothesis that the true mean reduction is not zero.

intuition: P-values represent the probability of observing a result as extreme or more extreme than what you actually observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true.
